Chapter 25: Extensive Explanation
Though one may recite a thousand words without meaning, what benefit is there?
It is better to understand a single phrase, hearing which one can attain the Way.

Though one may recite a thousand words without meaning, what benefit is there? This is because when people are in the world, they often recite and learn widely, but do not understand principles or meanings, and also do not comprehend the meaning of flavors and phrases, just like a person who carries hundreds of thousands of bundles of grass and wood, which can only be laborious and useless for the time being.
Therefore it is said, Though one may recite a thousand words without meaning, what benefit is there?

It is better to understand a single sentence, hearing which one can attain the Way. As in the past there was a person who stored much wealth and had plenty of grain and food. Wishing to travel far, he sold his family's grain to obtain treasures, accumulating countless precious things. Later, he again used many treasures to exchange for fine silver, but then found it too much, so he used the fine silver to trade for purple gold, but again found it too much. At that time, he used the fine gold to exchange for priceless wish-fulfilling maá¹‡i jewels, and all his wishes were fulfilled without fail.
This is also like that. Although one may study much, if one does not understand the meaning of the sentences, understanding a single meaning will surely bring about attainment.
Therefore it is said, It is better to understand a single sentence, hearing which one can attain the Way.

Although one recites a thousand phrases with the complete meaning of the Dharma, many people study and accomplish the meaning, but if they are unable to contemplate the meaning, they will fall by themselves and not reach the ultimate. Therefore, it is said: Although one recites a thousand phrases with the complete meaning of the Dharma.

Hearing a single phrase of the Dharma, one can follow it to extinguish the mind. In the world, there are many people who are well-versed and knowledgeable, able to contemplate a single phrase up to a hundred thousand meanings, with each meaning following the next without losing the thread, gradually reaching the great path of the unconditioned. Therefore, it is said: Hearing a single phrase of the Dharma, one can follow it to extinguish the mind.
Even if one lives a hundred years, with precepts violated and an unsettled mind, it is not as good as a single day of making offerings to those who uphold the precepts.

Although one may live a hundred years, if one's precepts are broken and one's mind is unstable, one who violates the precepts does not protect the three matters, sitting in meditation, reciting the sutras, and assisting. Such a person should not be associated with. Although one may stay in the world for a long time accumulating evil, after death one enters hell and receives countless sufferings, such as fire carts, furnaces, charcoal, knife mountains, and sword trees. The same is true for animals and hungry ghosts. Therefore, it is said: Although one may live a hundred years, if one's precepts are broken and one's mind is unstable.

It is not as good as one day of making offerings to a person who upholds the precepts. A person who upholds the precepts practices concentration and wisdom. The merit of one day is countless and immeasurable, and cannot be compared with analogies. If one stays in the world for a long time accumulating immeasurable virtue, if one is reborn in the heavens one naturally receives blessings. Therefore, it is said: It is not as good as one day of making offerings to a person who upholds the precepts.
Although one may live a hundred years, without wisdom and an unstable mind, it is not as good as one day of
wisdom and concentration.

Although one may live a hundred years without wisdom or certainty, there are many in the world who do not know shame or conscience, no different from the six domestic animals, like camels, mules, donkeys, elephants, horses, pigs, and dogs, without any distinction of high or low status.

A person without wisdom is also like this. Wrapped in foolishness and darkness, they do not know what is bright. Therefore, it is said: Although one may live a hundred years without wisdom or certainty.

It is not as good as one day of wisdom and certainty. A wise person deeply enters the scriptures. From one meaning to a hundred thousand meanings, contemplating and turning over is not difficult. Therefore, it is said: It is not as good as one day of wisdom and certainty.
Although one may live a hundred years, lazy and not diligent,
It is not as good as one day of diligence and not being timid.

Even if one lives a hundred years, if one is lazy and not diligent, it is like a person in the world who is always lazy and does not accomplish their wishes. Having fallen themselves, they cause others to be submerged in birth and death. Those who are self-deluded lose the five parts of the Dharma body and do not reach the place of the great path of no-action. They themselves are confused about the path and teach others to be submerged in birth and death.

If one accepts the food, bedding, bedding, and medicine of donors, but cannot digest them, from birth to death one will fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals. Even if one becomes a human, one will be in a borderland, after the Buddha's time, with worldly wisdom and eloquence, and in one of the eight difficult circumstances.
Why is this so?
It is all due to not accumulating merit in previous lives.
Therefore it is said, Even if one lives a hundred years, if one is lazy and not diligent.

It is not as good as one day of diligent progress without cowardice. Some people in the world are vigorously diligent and understand that the world is impermanent, that a human body is difficult to obtain, that encountering a Buddha's world is difficult, that being born in a central country is also difficult to encounter, and that having complete faculties is also difficult to obtain;
In the teachings of the sages, it is also unobtainable to seek to become a monk, and it is also unobtainable to hear the true Dharma.

A wise person who can understand this should diligently progress and seek the fruit of the path. It is also not difficult to attain nirvana. Having already accomplished it, one can then perfect the uncontaminated Dharma body.
Therefore, it is said: It is not as good as one day of diligent progress without cowardice.
Although one may live for a hundred years, not knowing the matter of birth and death,
It is not as good as one day of understanding the matter of birth and death.

Although one may live a hundred years, if one does not know about the arising and ceasing of things, one is in the world, deluded and unable to attain liberation. Even if one accumulates immeasurable offenses in a hundred years, one still does not know about the arising and ceasing of things. Although one may leave the household life and practice the Way, if one does not understand arising and ceasing within the teachings of the TathÄgata, one will always remain at the stage of an ordinary person and not reach the unconditioned. This is not the duty of a bhiká¹£u or Å›ramaá¹‡a, and one is far from the treasure-store of the TathÄgata and not close to the Buddha's teachings. Therefore it is said: Although one may live a hundred years, if one does not know about the arising and ceasing of things.

It is not as good as being born for one day and understanding the matter of birth and death. When a person is in the world, observing and penetrating all dharmas, one by one empty, the born do not know why they are born, the extinguished do not know why they are extinguished, being able to know the fundamental by distinguishing them one by one, even on the day of death, one is not afraid or fearful, and has nothing to be afraid of, the spirit and consciousness are not confused in the place where one is born, encountering sages and hearing the Dharma to attain liberation. Therefore, it is said, It is not as good as being born for one day and understanding the matter of birth and death.

To put it simply, observe the origin of pain. When a person is in the world, not knowing the origin of the extinction of pain, although being a bhiká¹£u, not penetrating the practice of a Å›ramaá¹‡a. Therefore, it is said, Observe the origin of pain.

One should observe the exhaustion of defilements. When a person's practice does not penetrate defilements, one will then be stuck in the three realms and five destinies, transmigrating through birth and death without a time to escape.

The wise one practices contemplation and observes this with outflows, knowing where they arise from and where they cease. Arising does not know why it arises, ceasing does not know why it ceases. Gradually reaching the realm without outflows.

One should further contemplate the trace of immovable practice. If there is a person who cannot contemplate the trace of immovable practice, he will fall and fall into birth and death. Although dwelling in Å›ramaá¹‡a, he is not a Å›ramaá¹‡a practitioner. Although dwelling in brÄhmaá¹‡a, he is not a brÄhmaá¹‡a practitioner.

By four things and conditions, although it is a profound Dharma, if a student contemplates and understands the trace of immovable practice, the mind does not waver or change, and gradually reaches the shore of the unconditioned.

One should further contemplate the trace of the practice of immortality. If a person in the world does not know about death and birth, death causes the spirit to be moved, and the wind goes next to the fire, the soul scatters, and the body becomes straight and has no feeling.

However, those who practice this path, wearing the Dharma robes, shaving their beards and hair, and donning the three Dharma robes, are unable to contemplate death as death and life as life, and are also unable to cultivate pure brahmacarya.

The so-called path to immortality is the extinction of nirvana, and thus one can enter the unconditioned state of the middle way, unborn, undying, free from old age and sickness, and tranquil and blissful.
Therefore, it is said, One should contemplate the path to immortality.
One should also contemplate the pure path, which is pure and not something to be learned by the defiled;
The path is able to remove defilements, and is not something to be learned by those who are defiled.

Next, one should contemplate the Dharma of the heavenly form, which cannot be seen or learned by ordinary people. It is the highest and most revered among all dharmas, and none can surpass it. It is the extinction of nirvana.

Practitioners contemplate the traces of the nectar practice, without thoughts of hunger or thirst, without thoughts of vexation or heat. Those who do not see it will forever fall into birth and death. Those who do not understand non-arising and attain the nectar are those who have perfected meritorious karma and give to others without stinginess.
Even if one lives for a hundred years, making offerings to the fire in the mountains and forests,
It is not as good as a moment of practice, carrying out the teachings and cultivating oneself.

Even if one lives for a hundred years, making offerings to the fire in the mountains and forests, in the past there was a brahman who toiled his body and suffered, making offerings to the fire god in the wilderness and deep mountains. He paid homage according to the seasons without violating the scriptures, selecting pure firewood and gathering fine flowers, burning various incense to make offerings in the hope of obtaining blessed merit.
At that time, the brahman withdrew and thought to himself:

I have been practicing strange arts on this mountain, thinking of this fire for a hundred years. Now I will test whether the fire knows gratitude and blessings. If it recognizes gratitude and nourishment, the evidence will be seen. If not, I will sacrifice to it again.
At that time, the brahman did not think things through. He immediately reached into the raging fire with both hands. His arms were burned and the pain was unbearable. The brahman thought to himself:
I have been sacrificing to the fire for so many years, wasting my efforts and suffering without benefit. Is it that my body is inviting this suffering?
At that time, there was a monk practicing on the mountain not far away. Knowing this, he asked:
Brahman, you should know!
Fire is hot by nature and does not distinguish between gratitude and nourishment, between high and low.

If you wish to know, I have a sage teacher who is the sole honored one in the three realms. When walking, he treads on emptiness without any obstruction. When sitting, he emits light that illuminates the ten directions. It would be good if we could go to him, personally pay respects, and fully hear his profound and mysterious Dharma. From this shore, we can reach the other shore.
When the brÄhmaá¹‡a heard this, his mind opened up and he was enlightened. He then went with the practitioner to where the Buddha was, bowed his head to the Buddha's feet, and stood to one side.
At that time, the World-Honored One observed that the brÄhmaá¹‡a was suitable for liberation. He spoke this verse in the great assembly:
Although one may live for a hundred years, offering sacrifices to the fire in the mountains and forests,

At that time, the brÄhmaá¹‡a suddenly became enlightened, all his dust and defilements were extinguished, and he attained the pure Dharma eye.
The Buddha told the brÄhmaá¹‡a:
In the past, you lived in the mountains for a hundred years, offering sacrifices to the fire and various gods. It was a waste of effort and did not lead to the ultimate.
You now know the true path, it is not as good as practicing it for a short while and cultivating it yourself.

People cling to foolishness until death, without achieving anything. For a hundred years, serving the fire, they do not awaken to themselves. Embracing foolishness, they throw themselves into the dark, unable to change themselves. If they can awaken and know that it is not true, always contemplating, knowing where the illness arises, where it comes from, and where it goes, they will fully understand that it is not a true and real Dharma.

If they further accept others' robes, food and drink, bedding, and medicine for illness, they will be able to digest them without loss. Serving and making offerings with named flowers, pounded incense, mixed incense, silk, and banners, such blessings are immeasurable.

Serving the fire for a hundred years is not as good as practicing loving-kindness for a short while, snapping one's fingers. Its blessings are the most honored and unsurpassed, difficult to describe, difficult to measure, and cannot be compared with analogies.

It is like comparing a mustard seed to Mount Sumeru, the water in a cow's hoofprint to the ocean, the dust on one's nails to the earth, a firefly to the sun. The merit of the mind of kindness is like this, let alone cultivating virtue for a hundred years and being fully endowed.
Riding on this merit for hundreds of thousands of kalpas, one never falls back into the stage of ordinary beings. Others look up to and respect him, all due to the accumulation of past practices.
Therefore it is said, it is not as good as a moment of practicing kindness with a single thought.
From month to month, the foolish one uses food to fill his stomach,
He has no faith in the Buddha, not even one-sixteenth of it.

From month to month, the foolish rely on food for sustenance. Some beings greedily cling to food and drink to nourish their bodies, not considering the calamities and disasters of the next world. The four elements that make up the body have different natures. The spirit resides within them, and consciousness distinguishes right from wrong. The wise recognize truth, while the foolish have inverted views. They do not know the good and evil deeds of this world and the next, and they wander through the three evil paths and eight difficulties without hope of escape.
Therefore it is said, From month to month, the foolish rely on food for sustenance.

If they do not have faith in the Buddha, they will not obtain even one-sixteenth of the merit, means that if there are sentient beings who, for a day, half a day, an hour, half an hour, or even the snap of a finger, have sincere faith in the Buddha without wavering, their merit is immeasurable and incalculable, and cannot be compared by analogy. The merit will be mysteriously repaid, without form or appearance, and will suddenly arrive by itself, with inexhaustible blessings and virtues.
Therefore it is said, If they do not have faith in the Buddha, they will not obtain even one-sixteenth of the merit.

To put it simply, they do not have faith in the Dharma, and for millions and millions of eons they only hear the sound of the Dharma once every sixteen times. The so-called Dharma is the extinction of nirvana.

As for not having a compassionate mind, out of the sixteen, one will not attain one. Sentient beings day and night harbor poison, entangled in anger, they eat each other. Because of harboring anger towards their parents, how could they have compassion to bless sentient beings?
This is not the case.
Therefore it is said, As for not having a compassionate mind, out of the sixteen, one will not attain one.

As for not having pity for sentient beings, out of the sixteen, one will not attain one. It is like the various realms and regions, the names and surnames of the sentient beings therein are innumerable;

If there are those who enter the meditation of loving-kindness, and within it they teach and transform, reaching the limits of the world to save the poor, not discriminating between good and ugly, and also not giving rise to thoughts of this can be given or this cannot be given, with equality and non-duality, one and without difference, this is called true giving.
Therefore it is said, Not with a mind of loving-kindness, one does not obtain even one out of sixteen.

There may be a country where the beings are called crawling creatures. Within it, one is courageous and does not avoid hard work, going to that country to provide what is needed without letting it be lacking. This is called a mind of giving.
Crawling creatures is not because of spirits. One does not obtain even one out of sixteen. It is not because of the true Dharma that beings fall into non-Buddhist teachings.
The Nirgrantha Jains and others call themselves honored ones, wrapping their stomachs in iron and walking around the world. They say to each other:

If there are sentient beings who give to these people, they will later obtain defiled and impure rewards. They will encounter evil in dreams and upon awakening. How much more so if they practice the Way and associate with them!
Therefore, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:

If one can have unwavering faith in the true Dharma, encounter hundreds of thousands of difficulties and hardships without changing one's mind, and single-mindedly believe without practicing inverted views, then this is called the TathÄgata's true Dharma.

Those who do not believe in it have not attained even one-sixteenth of it. Those who have faith in the true Dharma have immeasurable blessings that cannot be calculated. Hundreds of times, thousands of times, millions of times, billions of times, it cannot be compared with any analogy.

They sacrifice to the gods and shrines for an entire year, and the waste and loss of the people's wealth is also incalculable.

Those without faith harbor hatred and jealousy, causing disputes between people,
The wise shun them, the foolish take it as pleasure to practice.

Those who are without faith, harbor hatred and jealousy, and cause strife between others, in this world, people's faith is not firm, and they also do not believe in the Buddha, Dharma, Saá¹…gha, the true nature of the four noble truths, suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, even if they accumulate wealth up to heaven, it cannot be relied upon. It is like a bird that originally greedily eats meat, on a mountain tree there are leaves that resemble the color of meat, it watches and captures day and night, stretching its neck and looking up, the tree's meat-like leaves fall and become leaves, entangled by delusion it does not awaken by itself, like this it does not cease and loses its life there.
Why is it so?
All due to the greedy mind not changing by itself.

The words heard here are passed on to the other side, and if heard from the other side, they are passed back here, causing discord between the two sides and preventing them from achieving success. Jealousy arises in the mind and gives rise to defilements. Therefore it is said, Those without faith harbor hatred and cause discord between the two sides.

What is rejected by the wise - the wise know the proper etiquette, avoid suspicion, and do not dwell in confusion. They do not associate with others even for a moment, let alone spend time with them in the end.

The so-called wise are those who understand the past and present, are well-versed in many matters, prevent future problems, and do not act improperly. Their words and deeds match, and their speech is faultless. They discern profound meanings without error, and from a single phrase, they can expound countless teachings. The foolish are confused by this. Therefore it is said, What is rejected by the wise.

As for the foolish practice it as pleasure, suppose there is a person who, with a good heart, admonishes and encourages the ignorant, teaching them the Way to see the Way, but they do not follow the teachings and instead give rise to further doubts, taking hell as their hall and room, not considering the roots of misfortune and calamity in the afterlife, teaching and practicing evil karma without following good teachings, and falling further into hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. Therefore it is said, the foolish practice it as pleasure.
Having faith without hatred or jealousy, diligently practicing and having much learning,
The wise respect and serve them, the sages take it as pleasure.

As for having faith and being free from hatred and jealousy, it is like a person who deeply believes in the Buddha's teachings and the noble assembly, wholeheartedly believing and understanding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path, without harboring flattery or deceit, with a gentle and pliable mind, serving and respecting those who practice pure conduct, diligently receiving teachings during the day and practicing walking meditation at night, diligently and tirelessly without losing proper deportment, with a harmonious and pleasant countenance, first smiling and then speaking without harming others' intentions. Therefore, it is said, having faith and being free from hatred and jealousy.

As for diligence, faith, and much learning, among the practices cultivated by people, diligence is supreme, let alone extensively studying and acquiring much learning. Precepts, learning, giving, and wisdom are widely disseminated to all, peacefully abiding in the unconditioned and peacefully dwelling in the place of enlightenment, demonstrating what one has seen to others. Therefore, it is said, diligence, faith, and much learning.

The wise respect and serve him means that one should always be close to and receive from those who are not yet perfect in the precepts, and help them to become perfect in the precepts, concentration, wisdom, insight, and liberation. Therefore, it is said, The wise respect and serve him.

The sages take it as joy means that when people practice and follow the sages, they do not complain of the cold and hardship. Even if they encounter seven thousand koá¹­is of difficulties, they can abandon their lives. Although they encounter such suffering, they do not waver in their resolve. Therefore, it is said, The sages take it as joy.ğŸ”½Do not associate with bad friends,

Always join with the right Dharma.

As for not associating with bad friends, when practitioners encounter bad friends, their bad behavior increases day by day, and they fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animals. Even if they practice with a pure mind, they are tainted by evil. It is like a person who loves dogs, pigs, or sheep, and their mind does not depart from them. Dogs and pigs follow and are not separated, and what dogs and pigs enjoy is the best, and the latrines are bathing pools, and they defile each other. Those who associate with bad friends are also like this, following each other, and in the end there is no goodness.
Therefore it is said, do not associate with bad friends.

As for not associating with those who do not follow the Dharma, those who do not follow the Dharma are those who commit the five heinous crimes, have no precepts, no faith, no learning, no wisdom, and no giving. Such people cannot be befriended. Those who follow them as companions fall into evil destinies and do not reach good places. Therefore it is said, do not associate with those who do not follow the Dharma.

As for associating with good friends, one learns from them daily, their speech is gentle, and their thoughts are in harmony. Even if they make mistakes, they do not hurt others' feelings. They smile first and then speak, and their words are appropriate. Therefore, it is said, associate with good friends.

As for always meeting with the true Dharma, the true Dharma assembly refers to the Buddha, pratyekabuddhas, and Å›rÄvakas. Apart from the Buddha, there are no other sentient beings who surpass the Buddha. Apart from the Buddha and pratyekabuddhas, there are no other sentient beings who surpass the pratyekabuddhas. Apart from the Buddha and pratyekabuddhas, there are no other sentient beings who surpass the Å›rÄvakas. Those who have faith in these three will attain the ultimate and will not fall into the three evil paths of difficulty and danger. Therefore, it is said, always meet with the true Dharma.
Those who practice the path think of prevention and protection, and uphold the precepts and listen to much learning.
They contemplate immeasurable realms, and hear the good teachings of others.
Each knows the distinctions.

As for thinking of prevention on the road, when a group of people are on the road, they speak with caution, because in the wilderness there are many ghosts and spirits. If they speak evil, the spirits will take advantage of them, but if they discuss good things, the ghosts and spirits will protect them. Wherever they go, they will not encounter bad people, nor will they meet robbers. Therefore it is said, thinking of prevention on the road.

As for the person of precepts and much learning, they uphold the Buddha's teachings and do not let them leave their minds. As the Buddha said, he told the monks to cultivate samÄdhi and concentration, whether walking or sitting, not letting it be lost, then they will be seen and protected by the devas and spirits.
Why is this so?
It is all because of receiving and upholding the true Buddha's teachings.
Therefore it is said, the person of precepts and much learning.

As for immeasurable realms of thought, day and night they think of sitting in meditation, reciting the sÅ«tras, precepts, hearing, giving, and wisdom. Therefore it is said, immeasurable realms of thought.

Hearing those good teachings, each knows the distinctions. Just as those learners hear those good teachings, their minds are not confused or disordered, the phrases correspond, and they attain the fruits of the path, the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship, increasing their wholesome roots to the unconditioned path. Therefore it is said, Hearing those good teachings, each knows the distinctions.
Approaching evil, one sinks by oneself; cultivating goodness leads to fame.
The wonderful ones are always wonderful themselves, this is due to the true reality of the body.

Approaching evil, one sinks by oneself. It is like someone who associates with evil friends, only losing day by day without reaching the ultimate, just as the half-moon has darkness and no great brightness. Associating with evil friends is also like this, daily losing wholesome roots and increasing unwholesome dharmas. Therefore it is said, Approaching evil, one sinks by oneself.
